item.question:
You are logged in as root, and want to execute the command ls as user fordp.
You do not know his password.
How would you do this?
item.choice: It is not possible, because you do not know his password.
item.hint: You are root and as the root user you can become any user without providing a password.

item.question: Which command is used to change the owner of a particular file?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
When you run the command mycommand you want to redirect the output to a file.
Which command will accomplish this and will make sure no other output is sent to the console?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which of the following is considered the best order for specifying a command at the commandline in Bash?
item.hint: Although multiple choices provide a correct commandline the question asks for the best order. This means the most complete correct description.

item.question:
Suppose user pete has created a new application atop, and copied it to the directory /usr/local/bin.
On your system each user belongs to his/her own unique group.
For instance, user petra belongs to the group petra and pete belongs to the group pete.
You would like all the users who do not belong to the group and are not owner of the application to be able to run your application.
Which of the following command lines would allow the appropriate access?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
You downloaded a compressed file and want to display the contents (filenames) before extracting it.
The name of the downloaded file is stableos.tar.bz2.
Which single command (no options) can you use?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
When you create a new directory, you see the permissions are set to rwx--x---.
Which umask value would cause this to happen?
item.hint: When creating a directory the command <font face="monospace">mkdir</font> asks for a certain set of permissions and <font face="monospace">umask</font> is used to determine what the directory will eventually get. In general, the permissions asked when creating a directory are different from when creating a new file.

item.question: Which option can be used with the shutdown command to skip checking the filesystems on reboot?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
On a system that has the above uptime.
Which command is best used to print out system boot messages?
item.hint: The kernel keeps the messages in a buffer in memory. This buffer is limited and when full messages are removed using a first in first out algorithm.

item.question: Which of the following commands can be used to examine kernel bootup messages after boot time?
item.hint: Some questions allow multiple answers. Sometimes the question will state how many correct answers are required, in this case not. If you do not know the answer immediately the best strategy is eliminating the answers you know are wrong and select the best answer from the ones that are left. Sometimes another question might give you a clue for a previous question. You can always come back to this question later on.

item.question: Which filesystems are mounted using <font face="monospace">/etc/fstab</font> when you issue the command <font face="monospace">mount -a</font>?
item.choice: All filesystems except those on removable media.
None, you forgot to specify a device-file and mount location.
All filesystems except those that have <font face="monospace">noauto</font> specified as mount-option.
item.correct_answer: All filesystems except those that have <font face="monospace">noauto</font> specified as mount-option.
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
You have added a sound card and suspect it might be conflicting with another device.
Therefore you check the file /proc/____________ to learn which IRQs are being used by other drivers loaded by the kernel.

You want to use shared libraries that are in /home/guru1/mylibs (which is not in the standard library search path).
What is the appropriate command to use these libraries.
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which command will produce the above output?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which of the following statements about symbolic links is true?
item.choice: A symbolic link can be recognized by the character <font face="monospace">l</font> as being the most-left character in the output of <font face="monospace">ls -l</font>.
It is not possible to point a symbolic link to a directory in another filesystem.
The filesize of a symbolic link is always less than 256 bytes.
The command <font face="monospace">find / -type s</font> only displays symbolic links.
A symbolic link does not have its own inode-number.
item.correct_answer: A symbolic link can be recognized by the character <font face="monospace">l</font> as being the most-left character in the output of <font face="monospace">ls -l</font>.
The filesize of a symbolic link is always less than 256 bytes.
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: What is a disadvantage of using symbolic links over hard links?
item.choice: A symbolic link becomes disconnected from the underlying file if the file is moved.
A symbolic link can span different filesystems
The hard link uses the same inode as the original file, where a symbolic link has its own inode.
Removing a symbolic link does not remove the underlying file.
item.correct_answer: A symbolic link becomes disconnected from the underlying file if the file is moved.
item.hint: Although you personally might find more than one of the choices a disadvantage, the question is actually which of the following is the most disadvantage.

item.question: What is the devicefile of the first primary partition on the second SCSI-harddisk?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which command will set the the default permissions for new files to <font face="monospace">rw-r-----</font>, regardless of the current setting?
item.hint: Beware that using the numeric notation you specify what <font face="monospace">umask</font> should block. Using the symbolic notation you specify what <font face="monospace">umask</font> should let through.

item.question:
You are working on a Debian system and you made a mess of the samba configuration file.
Unfortunately you forgot to create a backup of the configuration file.
Which of the following would allow you to make a fresh start with the initial samba configuration from the debian samba package?
item.choice: It is not possible without reinstalling samba.

item.question: On a Debian system, which command will list all installed packages?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which file/directory usually has a sticky bit?
item.choice: Every file that needs to stay memory-resident.
item.hint: When the question mentions something in general you must assume how things are done in Debian or RedHat system or specified in the Filesystem Hierarchy Standard.

item.question: What is the result of the above command?
item.choice: You will get the shell secondary prompt
The text echo ATcomputing will be printed
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
You want to see detailed information of the installed package samba.
Which RPM command would provide you this information?

item.question:
You want to remove a package from the system completely, including its configuration files.
Which dpkg command-option(s) should you use?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: What will the above command do?
item.choice: Write the directory listing to the file <font face="monospace">contents.txt</font>
Write all directories and files to the file <font face="monospace">contents.txt</font>
Write all directories and files and errors to the file <font face="monospace">contents.txt</font>
Write all directories and files to the file <font face="monospace">contents.txt</font> and discard errors
item.correct_answer: Write all directories and files and errors to the file <font face="monospace">contents.txt</font>
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: What is one of the purposes of the Filesystem Hierarchy Standard?
item.choice: It enables software to predict the location of files and directories.
It enables software to predict the ownership and permissions of files and directories.
It states which formatting (e.g. <font face="monospace">ext3</font>) should be used for which filesystem.
It states the default size of the filesystems.
item.correct_answer: It enables software to predict the location of files and directories.
item.hint: You may find none of the answers applicable. However, by eliminating answers that are obviously wrong you should able to find the correct answer.

item.question: Which command will display a list with all installed RPMs?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which option can be used with the shutdown command to <font face="monospace">fsck</font> on the next reboot?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: What option will allow a normal user to mount a filesystem and have only the user that mounted the filesystem unmount it?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: What is the default signal the <font face="monospace">kill</font> command sends to a process when the signal is not specified?

item.question:
You enter a command (mycmd) in bash and want to redirect both standard output and standard error output to one file (mylog).
Select all correct answers.
item.hint: This is a tricky question. If you know your I/O redirection rules you will probably find one correct answer quickly. But there are actually two correct answers. Before the shell will fork and execute the command it will have rewritten the commandline and removed all special characters and words from the commandline. So the order may not be that important.

item.question: Which file is the main configuration file for the init process?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
A user calls claiming she gets an error message saying there is no space left on the device when creating a new file.
Which command would you use to verify the problem?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
You downloaded some software and installed it under /usr/local.
When you run the command it fails with the above error message.
You located the file in /usr/local/lib.
How would you proceed to solve this issue permanently?
item.choice: Add <font face="monospace">/usr/local/lib/</font> to the variable <font face="monospace">LD_LIBRARY_PATH</font>.
Move the file <font face="monospace">libkapp.so.1</font> to <font face="monospace">/usr/lib</font>.
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which command will show the first 10 lines of a file by default?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which run level(s) can be used as administration mode?
item.hint: Any runlevel that allows you to log in can be used to administer the system.

item.question: With Xorg 7.0, what is the name of the configuration file?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: What best describes the above commandline when executed?
item.choice: <font face="monospace">cat</font> reads from the file <font face="monospace">/etc/passwd</font> through stdin and pipes the output to <font face="monospace">grep</font>
<font face="monospace">cat</font> reads the files <font face="monospace"><</font> and <font face="monospace">/etc/passwd</font> and sends the output to <font face="monospace">grep</font>
No output as <font face="monospace">guru1</font> is not a valid username
item.correct_answer: <font face="monospace">cat</font> reads from the file <font face="monospace">/etc/passwd</font> through stdin and pipes the output to <font face="monospace">grep</font>
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which command will display all the lines of the file <font face="monospace">foo</font> starting with a capital S?
item.hint: The question asks for a regular expression that matches a capital S at the beginning of each line.

item.question:
The user guru1 complains that he cannot access his homedirectory.
Given the directory /home/guru1 has the above permissions.
Which of the following commands would fix this problem?

item.question:
Which command would allow you to remove a file on a filesystem without actually mounting it?
Choose all that apply.
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which command can be used to show all shell-variables?
item.hint: The Bash shell treats all variables equal but some are more equal than others. The most equal variables are exported to its children and the others are not. The question is about showing ALL variables, so not only the exported ones.

item.question:
What would be the correct command to remove the package atop completely from a Debian system?
Select two.
item.hint: By default removing a package under Debian will not remove the configuration files as well.

item.question:
A job is running in the foreground.
Pressing [Ctrl]+[KEY] pauses this job and gives you control of the terminal.
What is [KEY]?
item.hint: The question is about a key combination pressing the control key and another key. The answer you must provide is the letter of the other key.

item.question: The kernelfile vmlinuz-2.6.18 is in the ________ directory.
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer. Note that the question does not explicitly state you should provide the absolute path as well. Your safest bet is to provide the absolute path.

item.question:

item.question: Which condition(s) must be true if two directories each require their own quotum for filesystem usage?
item.choice: They must exist on Ext3 partitions
The directories must have the setgid permission set.
They must be on different partitions
They must be mounted by the root user
item.correct_answer: They must be on different partitions

item.question:
Assume your current working directory is ~ and you wish to copy the files from the homedirectory of user guru1 to the directory temp in your homedirectory.
Which of the following commands will accomplish this?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
Consider the above exhibit.
As you can see bar is a symbolic link, pointing to foo.
As user guru1 you execute 'rm bar'.
What happens?
item.choice: Nothing, because <font face="monospace">bar</font> is no ordinary file.
Both <font face="monospace">foo</font> and <font face="monospace">bar</font> would be removed.
Only <font face="monospace">foo</font> would be removed, because <font face="monospace">bar</font> points to <font face="monospace">foo</font>.
You would be asked whether <font face="monospace">bar</font> or <font face="monospace">foo</font> should be removed.
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
Which commands would check the integrity of an ext2 filesystem?
Choose all that apply.

item.question: Which of the following commands will give you the usernames of all users that are running a proces at this moment:
item.hint: The question only requires you to provide the usernames. All other information provided by <font face="monospace">ps</font> may be discarded.

item.question:
You have a text file (hitchhiker.txt) in which you want to replace every 'arthur' by 'Arthur'.
You decide to use sed to make this happen.
What is the correct commandline?
item.hint: The question states you want to replace EVERY arthur with Arthur. Hence, you should do a global replacement. Also note that the file <font face="monospace">hitchhiker.txt</font> should be updated. The question does not mention anything about creating a new file.

item.question: What is the maximum amount of devices, not including the host adapter, you can connect to an 8 bit SCSI card?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
During installation of the package atop you encountered an error.
Which command will display the package status?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
You execute the above command.
What will be the result?
item.choice: Only filenames in the user's homedir will be listed in the file <font face="monospace">list.txt</font>
All directorynames will be listed in the file <font face="monospace">list.txt</font>
All filenames in the user's homedir and any errors reported by <font face="monospace">find</font> will be listed in the file <font face="monospace">list.txt</font>
All filenames in the user's homedir will be printed in the terminal and any errors will be written to <font face="monospace">list.txt</font>
item.correct_answer: All filenames in the user's homedir and any errors reported by <font face="monospace">find</font> will be listed in the file <font face="monospace">list.txt</font>
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.
